ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Can anbody help a Newbie?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Roland, I m no expert but thinking back to my university days this sounds very much like Job Shop Scheduling. This is quite a large well researched topic,

Hi Roland,

I'm no expert but thinking back to my university days this sounds very 
much like Job Shop Scheduling. This is quite a large well researched 
topic, and so I would expect a google search or a trip to a good library 
or bookstore to be useful.

Generally though neuro-evolution techniques such as NEAT aren't ideally 
suited to this type of problem, especially if the problem to be solved 
is fixed. By this I mean you are trying to solve a specific instance of 
the problem with, say 2 machines and 3 buckets, instead of the general 
case of  "What is the best solutions given x machines and y buckets?".

You say you have attempted to test every possible combination - the 
'brute force' approach. And you probably discovered that the number of 
combinations is very large and therefore you can't find a good solution 
in a reasonable amount of time (or even any time this millenium!). 
Therefore you might want to try a simple genetic algorithm which goes 
something like this:

1) Start with a fixed population of randomly generated solutions. Say 500.
2)  Evaluate each solution and assign a fitness value.
3)  Generate offspring from the fittest solutions using crossover and/or 
mutation.
4)  Goto 2. (next generation)


There are a great many variations on this theme. E.g. you can replace a 
small proportion of the population (keep the fittest solutions) per 
generation or the whole generation. How you represent the solutions is 
also important, so e.g. if you can think of an encoding that represents 
only legal solutions then that is a very good start. Otherwise you can 
assign a low fitness to solutions that are actually impossible (e.g. two 
machines filling the same bucket at the same time), but this will 
usually require searching for far longer in order to find a good solution.

The fitness function is very imporatant, any errors in the function will 
normally cause a search to find poor or completely useless solutions. 
However you can start out witha crude fitness function to test how well 
the approach works for your problem and then fine tune it as time 
allows, so for example you could factor in what are termed soft 
constraints, these are factors that won't make a solution invalid but 
that you would rather avoid (e.g. limit the distance machines have to 
travel between buckets).

I would expect that there is already a lot of job-shop scheduling 
software already in existence, so it's worth searching the web. If you 
do decide to write your own code then there are open source genetic 
algorithm code libraries available which might make the task 
considerably easier, following a little reading of documentation.

Hope that helps,

Colin.



schuller_esa wrote:

>Hi! 
>
>My Boss gave me the instruction to write Process optimizing Programm.
>First I thougt that it will be hard but possible. 
>By now I have an working alogithm. Which does the Job quite well. But
>now I got some additional rules, so that my Programm produces just
>junk.
>
>Were the problem:
>I have a number of (lets call them Buckets) 
>They are aligned in two rows.
>Then I have Two machinetypes. On for Filling and one for emtying the
>Buckets.
>The material has to go into one Bucket (stay for a while) then from
>this into anoter (again Stay) and into a third (stay) and then out.
>There are specific Buckets for each phase.
>
>Now I have some rules for the machines.
>one cannot go pass the other while it is filling.
>for emtying and filling it to another bucket i need two Machines.
>The buckets do not have eaquel size, but do always have to be full.
>An emtying machine must not leave a Bucket while it is not empty 
>....
>
>Some rules differ on each Plant.
>The goal is to get as much material through the mashine.
>
>So how do I have to get startet?!
>I Tried to think of an algorithm which tries every possible
>Combination
>(You can go asleep while its working. :-< )
>
>I discoverd NEAT for Delphi and thought that this could be the right
>thing. 
>But I didn't find any Quickstart or similar to use it. What Functions
>do I have to call? And the biggest Question: How should I connect the
>Gene? (Which to take for Input and for Output?)
>
>Is there any chance of constant learning? What if it generates an
>output against one of of the Rules. How to tell it that it was wrong?
>
>Can anybody point me tho the right direction.
>Btw. I use Delphi but I accept Ideas in every language.
>
>Roland Schuller, AUSTRIA
